item.title: Buildings don't fit in blockchains
item.description: How we learned to love graphs: Tokenising Buildings: A Graph-Based Approach to Digital Twins on the Blockchain
item.dc:creator: Adventurous Systems
item.content:encoded:
Bridging Physical Construction with Digital Assets Through TopologicPy, Graph Databases, and Ethereum

Thanks for reading! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

The Challenge: Buildings Don’t Fit on Blockchains

Building Information Modelling (BIM) has revolutionised how we design and construct buildings. IFC (Industry Foundation Classes) files capture everything from structural walls to HVAC ducts in rich, hierarchical detail. Meanwhile, blockchain technology promises immutable ownership records and programmable assets through NFTs.

But there’s a fundamental mismatch: buildings are *complex graphs* of interconnected components, while traditional blockchain tokenisation treats assets as isolated items. A wall isn’t just a rectangle—it connects to floors, supports beams, contains doors, and defines spaces. How do you preserve these critical relationships when moving from BIM software to blockchain?

This repository presents a novel solution: a complete pipeline that transforms IFC files into tokenised building graphs, preserving both spatial hierarchy and topological connectivity on Ethereum.

Four Stages of Transformation

Our system implements a sophisticated four-stage pipeline that maintains data fidelity from design file to blockchain token:

IFC File → TopologicPy Graph → Kuzu Database → Ethereum NFTs

(BIM) (Topology Analysis) (Graph Storage) (Ownership Layer)

1.IFC Processing with IfcOpenShell

The journey begins with **IfcOpenShell**, the industry-standard parser for IFC files. We extract:

- Spatial hierarchy: Project → Building → Storey → Space → Component

- Geometric data: 3D coordinates, dimensions, orientations

- Semantic metadata: GUIDs, classifications, material properties

- Relationships: Containment, connectivity, dependencies

This stage converts the IFC’s complex schema into Python objects, making the data accessible for graph analysis.

2.Topological Graph Generation with TopologicPy

Here’s where the innovation begins. TopologicPy transforms isolated building components into a dual graph structure:

- **Nodes** represent building elements (walls, spaces, columns)

- **Edges** represent topological relationships (adjacency, boundaries, openings)

Unlike simple parent-child trees, TopologicPy computes spatial connectivity:

- Which walls share faces?

- Which rooms connect through doors?

- Which beams support which slabs?

This creates a graph-based representation that captures how buildings actually work—not just how they’re organised in software.

**Technical Deep Dive:**

# TopologicPy creates dual graphs where:

# - Spatial elements become vertices

# - Shared boundaries become edges

# - IFC metadata attaches to dictionaries

# Each vertex preserves:

# - 3D coordinates (x, y, z)

# - IFC GUID (permanent identifier)

# - Type (IfcWall, IfcSpace, etc.)

# - Custom properties from IFC property sets

3.Graph Database Storage with Kuzu

Raw graphs are powerful but unwieldy. Kuzu, a high-performance embedded graph database, provides:

- Cypher-like queries for graph analytics

- Columnar storage for memory efficiency (60% less than Neo4j)

- Native graph operations (pathfinding, centrality analysis)

Kuzu becomes the source of truth for building analytics while preparing data for blockchain export.

4.Stage 4: Blockchain Tokenisation with ERC-998

The final transformation: Kuzu graphs become **composable NFTs** on Ethereum.

Smart Contract Architecture:

We implement **ERC-998** (Composable NFTs), extending standard ERC-721 with parent-child relationships, and developing a custom graph schema for lateral connections beyond the paren-child tree.

Dual Graph Representation:

The smart contract preserves BOTH relationship types:

1. Hierarchical (ERC-998): Building contains storeys, storeys contain spaces

2. Lateral (Adjacency List): Wall connects to wall, space connects to space

This creates a graph-isomorphic mapping: every node and edge in Kuzu has a corresponding token and relationship on-chain.

Token ID Encoding:

We use token ID prefixes for semantic clarity:

Project: 1,000,000,000,000 + projectId

Building: 2,000,000,000,000 + buildingId

Storey: 3,000,000,000,000 + storeyId

Space: 4,000,000,000,000 + spaceId

Component: 5,000,000,000,000 + componentId

This enables type inference from token ID alone—critical for efficient on-chain logic.

User Workflow:

1. Upload IFC file via Streamlit

2. TopologicPy processes into graph (2-45 seconds depending on size)

3. Kuzu stores graph for querying

4. Visualize 3D connectivity in browser

5. Export to blockchain (one-click minting)

Technical Achievements

Robust IFC Processing:

- Dual processing methods (Direct vs. Traditional)

- Multiple fallback strategies for problematic files

- 90%+ success rate across diverse IFC schemas

- Complete metadata preservation via TopologicPy Dictionary system

High-Performance Analytics:

- Sub-second graph queries for 1000+ node buildings

- Spatial queries (find connected spaces, circulation analysis)

- Centrality metrics (identify critical structural components)

Blockchain Integration:

- Single-transaction building graph minting

- On-chain graph traversal via adjacency lists

- Construction status tracking (design → completion)

- Ownership composability (sell individual floors, rooms, components)

Profound Implications for Construction

The paradigm shift begins with what it means to be a “digital twin.” Most implementations treat digital twins as disconnected visualisations—rich 3D models divorced from the asset’s operational reality and ownership structure. The graph-based approach fundamentally reimagines this relationship. By anchoring digital twins directly to blockchain-resident tokens, the system creates immutable records that preserve exact topology from design intent through construction completion. Each building component becomes queryable and verifiable; as construction progresses, contractors update token status directly on the ledger while IoT sensors feed real-time data that updates component tokens’ operational state. This transforms the digital twin from a static documentation artefact into a living, verifiable record—one where ownership is transparent, work completion triggers automated verification, and real-time data becomes cryptographic truth rather than system-dependent metadata.

Where traditional property ownership is binary—you own a building or you don’t—compositional NFTs unlock a fundamentally different model of asset structure. Using ERC-998 composability, a single building becomes a nested hierarchy where fractional ownership of specific components becomes possible: investors could own all HVAC systems across a portfolio without owning the buildings themselves; developers could rent just the commercial ground floor as a service while retaining deeper structure; modular construction gains semantic richness as prefabricated components arrive with their own NFTs, creating transparent supply chain provenance. This extends beyond mere financial slicing—component-level tokenization enables lifecycle tracking that proves the age of replaced equipment or certifies the data provenance of circular reused materials, creating new possibilities for insurance, warranties, and renovation markets that were logistically impossible before blockchain-resident graphs.

The technical pipeline—flowing from IFC design files through TopologicPy topology analysis into Kuzu’s queryable graphs and finally onto Ethereum’s composable NFTs—preserves design intent across the entire building lifecycle. During design, architects mint the initial graph from BIM data while smart contracts enforce approval workflows and track design changes as graph modifications. When construction begins, contractors progressively update token status as work completes, with quality verification timestamped on-chain and supply chain data integrated as materials with component tokens arrive on site. Upon operations, facility managers query the same graph structure for maintenance planning, while renovations update the graph topology directly—and crucially, compliance can be automatically verified against the original graph structure, eliminating manual auditing and creating permanent, verifiable records of what was built versus what was designed.

This technical infrastructure enables entirely new economic models previously impossible in construction. Performance contracting becomes verifiable and automatic: an HVAC installer receives payment the moment smart contracts confirm efficiency metrics meet targets by comparing sensor data against the component token’s specifications. Predictive maintenance markets emerge as graph neural networks train on historical failure patterns tied to specific component tokens, with insurance policies priced dynamically based on how critical or redundant components are within the overall topology. Most radically, successful building graphs themselves become marketable templates—architects can license proven topologies as design patterns while automated verification ensures new designs conform to approved, tested structures. What emerges is not merely tokenisation of static assets, but a complete inversion: the graph becomes the source of economic value, enabling markets that commodify successful design, operational efficiency, and component relationships rather than just bricks and mortar.

---

Not everything is rosy- MVPs come with Technical Challenges: Gas, Scale, and Trade-offs

This prototype demonstrates technical feasibility while revealing fundamental limitations:

The Gas Problem

Minting a complete building graph is expensive:

- Base transaction: ~200,000 gas

- Per node: ~150,000 gas (struct storage + mappings)

- Per edge: ~50,000 gas (adjacency list push)

The cost of the gas to mint a single building and the restriction of block size per transaction means that we can not really mint a single building in one transaction, and need to do it in batches, or by compressing metadata, most probably a layer 2 chain. Our final solution will follow a hybrid model, as our current prototype is not handling also multiple stakeholders and data spaces. The ideal solution would be to have a system that tracks all design and construction activity, maintaining a single graph that lives though in decentralised data spaces. Speckle partially does this for a design activity.

What Buildings on Blockchains Mean: Rethinking Representation

This project forces a question: What does it mean to put a building “on the blockchain”?

The naive approach treats buildings like static images—mint a token, attach metadata, done (and don’t get us started on the AI revolution that only ues diffusion models!~). But buildings are dynamic networks of interdependent components. Our graph-based approach recognises:

- Buildings are relationships, not just parts

- Topology matters for functionality and compliance

- Ownership can be compositional (fractal property rights)

The Decentralisation Paradox

Ironically, fully decentralising building data may be counterproductive:

- Graph queries are computationally expensive on-chain

- Storage costs make comprehensive metadata prohibitive

- Update frequency (design changes, construction progress) creates transaction bloat

The hybrid model acknowledges a deeper truth: Not all data needs blockchain’s guarantees. The blockchain should attest to ownership and integrity, while specialised systems (graph databases, IPFS) handle querying and storage.

This mirrors physical construction: the deed registry doesn’t contain building blueprints—it certifies who owns what. Our system extends this: blockchain certifies the graph topology’s integrity via hashes, while Kuzu provides the actual analytics.

Industry Transformation Pathways

If you find this interesting and you have a design or construction project that you would like to test this with, please email us and jump on a call with us! contact as at systems at adventurous.systems

You can find the CryptoTwin prototype here.

---

item.title: How AEC Firms Should Prepare for Artificial Intelligence: Essential Steps for the UK Construction Industry
item.description: Transforming Architecture, Engineering & Construction Through Strategic AI Implementation
item.dc:creator: Adventurous Systems
item.content:encoded:
by Dr Theo Dounas for Adventurous Systems

The Architecture, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industry stands at a pivotal moment. While traditionally resistant to technological change, forward-thinking AEC firms across the UK are recognising that artificial intelligence isn’t just another digital tool—it’s a fundamental shift that will determine which companies thrive in the next decade.

Thanks for reading! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

From automated design optimisation and predictive maintenance to intelligent project scheduling and risk assessment, AI has the potential to revolutionise how we design, build, and manage construction projects. UK AEC firms that embrace this transformation today will gain unprecedented competitive advantages: reduced project timelines, minimised cost overruns, enhanced safety protocols, and the ability to tackle increasingly complex architectural challenges.

However, successful AI integration in the AEC sector requires more than purchasing new software. It demands a comprehensive digital transformation strategy that addresses the unique challenges of construction workflows, regulatory compliance, and the collaborative nature of building projects.

Digital Infrastructure Transformation for AEC

The foundation for AI readiness in any AEC firm begins with robust digital infrastructure that can handle the complexity of modern construction data. Unlike other industries, AEC firms must manage diverse data streams: Building information models, project schedules, cost databases, regulatory requirements, site conditions, and real-time construction progress monitoring.

UK construction companies must transition from fragmented, project-based data silos to integrated digital ecosystems. This means upgrading legacy CAD systems to cloud-based BIM platforms, implementing unified project management systems, and establishing data standards that enable AI tools to access and analyse information across all project phases.

Firms need to rethink how design data flows from architects to engineers to contractors. AI-powered tools can only deliver value when they can seamlessly access accurate, up-to-date information from all stakeholders. This requires standardised file formats, consistent naming conventions, and integrated workflows that connect design intent with construction reality, all orchestrated and integrated across platforms.

Modern AEC firms are discovering that effective AI implementation isn’t about replacing existing tools but creating intelligent connections between them. When BIM software communicates effectively with cost estimation tools, project schedules sync with resource management systems, and site data feeds back into design models, AI can identify patterns, predict problems, and optimise outcomes in ways previously impossible. In construction, artificial intelligence can help monitor and analyse inventory in construction sites, minimising losses and slashing operating fat.

Looking over the Horizon: the Digital Construction Era

These changes require leadership that understands both technological possibilities and construction realities. Partners, directors, and practice leaders must foster a clear vision that resonates throughout the organisation. With tight margins in the sectors, AEC transformations can only succeed when leadership teams embrace calculated innovation. This means developing pilot projects that test AI applications in real construction scenarios, encouraging teams to experiment with new design workflows, and create an environment where the organisation’s knowledge on technology grows collectively alongside construction expertise.

Within this ongoing process, organisations need to establish frameworks for continuous technology evaluation, create pathways for staff to develop digital skills, and ensure that AI initiatives align with broader business objectives including client satisfaction, project profitability, and industry reputation.

From Building Buildings to Building Skills: Your AEC Team

The construction industry’s greatest asset has always been its skilled workforce. Far from the fears of replacing human ingenuity, AI integration amplifies human experience. This means that AEC firms must invest in comprehensive skills development that enables architects, engineers and construction professionals to work effectively alongside intelligent systems.

This can only happen with an honest assessment of current digital capabilities across all roles. Many AEC professionals excel at traditional design and construction methods but get confused with computational thinking, data analysis and AI-powered design tools. These gaps can be addressed using targeted training programmes, while building on the depth of existing expertise.

Beyond parametric design and integrating data -driven insights, working with predictive analytics for project planning or leveraging automated cost estimation and quality control systems, the most important skill is asking the right question: When and where can Artificial Intelligence provide valuable insights and when should human judgement remain paramount?

At the core of upgrading their skills, progressive AEC firms are creating internal AI champions: experienced professionals who combine deep construction knowledge with emerging digital capabilities. These individuals become bridges between traditional practices and innovative approaches, helping colleagues understand how AI tools can enhance their work rather than complicate it.

AEC Automation and AI Readiness assessment by Adventurous Systems

Recognising that every AEC firm starts their digital journey from a different vantage point, we at Adventurous Systems have developed an AI readiness assessment exercise specifically for the UK construction industry. This comprehensive evaluation examines the technological maturity, data management practices, and digital capabilities that determine readiness for AI implementation in AEC contexts.

Our assessment evaluates critical factors from digitisation of processes to BIM implementation, data integration capabilities, staff digital literacy, project management system effectiveness and regulatory compliance. We examine, in three phases, discovery, evaluation and recommendation, your firm’s technological maturity, data management practices, and digital capabilities. This allows you to understand how well existing workflows and levels of skills can accommodate AI-powered tools and identify specific areas where your digital infrastructure requires enhancement.

The Adventurous Systems AEC assessment goes beyond technology evaluation. We analyse organisational culture, change management capabilities, and strategic alignment to ensure AI initiatives will be successfully adopted and sustained. Our team understands the unique pressures of construction projects—tight deadlines, complex stakeholder relationships, and regulatory requirements—and designs recommendations that work within these realities.

Each assessment culminates in a detailed roadmap that prioritises AI implementation opportunities based on potential impact, implementation complexity, and organisational readiness. This ensures that AEC firms can begin their AI journey with confidence, focusing on applications that will deliver measurable value while building capabilities for more advanced implementations.

The Competitive Advantage of AI-Ready AEC Firms

UK construction companies that successfully integrate AI will gain significant competitive advantages. Automated design optimisation reduces iteration cycles, predictive analytics minimise project risks, and intelligent resource management improves profitability. These capabilities become increasingly important as clients demand faster delivery, more complex solutions, and greater cost certainty.

AI-powered AEC firms can offer services that traditional competitors cannot match: predictive maintenance strategies for complex building systems, optimised designs that balance aesthetic goals with performance requirements, and project management approaches that proactively address potential issues before they impact timelines or budgets.

As the UK construction industry faces ongoing challenges including skills shortages, sustainability requirements, and increasing project complexity, AI becomes a strategic differentiator. Firms that master these capabilities today will be positioned to lead tomorrow’s construction landscape.

Conclusion

The integration of artificial intelligence into AEC operations represents more than technological advancement—it’s a fundamental evolution in how we approach design, construction, and building management. Success requires comprehensive transformation that addresses technology infrastructure, leadership vision, workforce development, and strategic planning.

For UK AEC firms, the question isn’t whether to adopt AI, but how quickly and effectively they can build these capabilities. The companies that begin this journey today, with proper assessment, strategic planning, and expert guidance, will define the future of British construction.

Adventurous Systems stands ready to guide your AEC firm through this transformation. Our specialised expertise in construction technology, combined with deep understanding of AI implementation, makes us the ideal partner for your digital evolution.
